My guess is that the force of the block being pulled out needs to overcome the force of friction quickly enough that it doesn't affect the blocks directly above it, primarily because if the bottom section moves, the acceleration will disperse throughout the whole system, and the speed of the top will not equal the speed of the bottom, causing a displacement. This means that it is very improbable to pull this off with conventional methods.

How is this a myth? Physically speaking, it’s 100% possible. Similar to pulling a tablecloth underneath plates and shit and leaving everything still. Just have to be fast enough and horizontal enough to not disturb the rest of the tower. Not impossible, just incredibly difficult. Friction and any deviation that disturbs the tower is what makes it difficult. The stability and evenness of the rest of tower is also very impactful on the probability of success. Roughness of block is also important in affecting stability and amount of friction. Was never impossible so whoever started this myth clearly never went to school or didn’t bother to think it through clearly.

The jumbo size jenga blocks have another important factor than just the weight. Real Jenga blocks, especially old ones than have been used a lot, are not all perfectly the same. There’s always small imperfections and wear that develops that affect how much friction the blocks have against each other. It’s a big part of why some pieces slide out like butter while others even in hypothetically easier to remove configurations won’t come out without pulling down the tower. Handmade wooden blocks, while not perfect either, don’t have quite the same smoothness and variance of classic Jenga blocks. I’ve played with jumbo lawn Jenga and it is not the same at all. The table material and the amount of friction it causes is also a factor

The composition of the tower's stacked pieces is everything.  The crashes all occurred when there was a gap in a middle layer that was opposite the direction of the bottom piece's momentum, allowing the stack above that gap to rock backward.  There were two such layers on the blue actuator at the end, which worked due to its speed.  It failed on the big blocks because it had a brief pause between striking and exiting the stack (seen using 'pause, comma, period' frame advance), probably due to its weight.  A more powerful actuator might have worked on the big block stack.
